TopDocs.Snippet: unfortunately just having an afab practitioner wouldn't guarantee your success unless they're actively aware of the issue. it's kind of an issue with the whole practice, but definitely still a lot more with men. bias is unfortunately an extremely deciding factor and a lot of practitioners also still

i'm audhd so creating and understanding analogies might not be my strong suit, but i'll try. the fire analogy doesn't resonate with me, because i don't really think being neurodivergent is painful in the sense that being on fire would be. if i were to do a pain analogy i would go with something i've

having adhd itself doesn't feel like anything. or at least, not that i can tell. that's something that made me doubt it pre-diagnosis. but it's because it's something neurological. i never had a typical brain, i don't know how it feels like to have adhd, because i have nothing to compare it to.

i am also in scotland, self referred to the new adult autism service 6 weeks after it launched in 2021, had my assessment earlier this year. so almost 3 years on the waiting list. according to a local foi request quoted in a newspaper article last year (requested by my msp) then had only completed 5

bit late, but i fully agree. i only realized it when i was 35 and first read about aspergers, after reading the symptoms the missing links suddenly appeared. i was tested and diagnosed, and then i really knew. (well, i knew, only not officially) before that i had a different idea of what autism is,

i think you owe it to your son to help him and if your husband is not on board with the diagnosis. then keep him out of the loop, as best you can. don't debate your husband that usually results in people doubling down on their cognitive dissonance. do anything you can do help your son and just don't

i think male pride could be an obstacle here. just because your son has challenges does not make him any lesser of a person. we all have talent tapping that resource and encouraging it to overcome obstacles in life is possible. that said autism i believe has many levels and his diagnosis should not

yes, it could be denial on your husband's part. still, that's his burden to wear, and wearing it down on your son by denying his autism is not a responsible thing to do. i also feel like denying who he is is wrong and will only cause more problems down the road. 100% this. autism is and always will

i only got my diagnosis earlier this year (i'm 21) and i had to drop out of college because my undiagnosed anxiety issues which stem from my autism made doing homework difficult (and i suspect the autism itself might have played a role). i've been struggling to hold down a job and get my license as

is your husband also autistic but deflecting the diagnosis because he doesn’t have one himself? my dad argued with every specialist we saw when i was getting diagnosed as a kid because all of the things they talked about were “just normal things like when i was growing up just like my father”. he wa

aba is basically forcing autistic people to be less autistic and to appear more allistic- which doesn’t work- it leads to heavy autistic masking which leads to burnout- there is a reason why we have a high suicide rate in our community- we need more advocacy of acceptance and not forced masking at t

the person who is commenting is coming from a place of knowledge about aba practices of yore. they do not treat aba like that anymore, for the most part. sure there may be some agencies that still have practices of preventing stims but every aba therapy i’ve encountered over the past couple of years
so happy to hear that your son is having success with aba! i am glad to hear another parent that loves aba therapy!

that is what i tell everyone! she’s made more progress in the first 2 weeks of aba than she did in a year of speech therapy with 2 different speech language pathologists! so glad your son is making progress with his speech!

thank you for your comment! yes, i agree - the one on one time and for the length of time she goes (monday-friday) vs 2 days a week of speech makes all the difference! grateful for our slps but after a year we had to try adding something else to her therapy plan and we are so glad we did!

i love aba therapy. i was weary of it at first too because it’s a lot of hours everyday, but where i live the therapist will actually come to my house so it makes it a lot easier. my son has been having therapy about as long as your daughter and he’s doing so great with it! some of his goals were to

yeah. my therapy was never marketed as aba i don't believe. however, some of the things i went through seem to resemble the horror stories i have heard of it. i haven't heard about any medications being used in aba though, so i don't know. my treatment was probably some kind of mix. the place i went

also to add to this; if you are in america i see a lot of people saying that they label themselves as aba because it’s all that insurance will pay for, but that the therapy they do isn’t actually aba. i would encourage speaking to the therapist about the specific concerns about it and see what there

hello! i am a practicing bcba. you are correct, there is some malpractice both in the history of aba and in current practitioners who are not up to speed on the changes the aba community has worked hard on to make sure we are ethical, compassionate, and don’t dim people’s wonderful sparks. i appreci

if you are 14 or older it is your legal right to accept or reject medical treatments and that includes therapy. if you're under 14, well, no one can actually make you participate in therapy. legally, you are only required to be physically present. i would suggest explaining to your therapist why you

i've been to a few different therapists with different methods and it's been unhelpful at best and traumatizing at worst. most of them weren't specialized in autism, the ones that were, were generally better. i do think it's kept me from getting effective support for example occupational therapy. in

i actually just broke up with my therapist last night lol. but before her, i was seeing the person who told me i might have autism. she ended up moving to canada and tbh it’s been really hard to get over it. she was like a friend to me (i don’t have any) and i made so much progress with her. she did

she did! they just didn’t work. my psychologist felt like the emdr was causing more harm to she stopped it and we switched to regular talk therapy for a few more years. eta - i wrote “didn’t give me the tools” when i probably should’ve written “i didn’t have the ability to regulate”

i’m a therapist in therapy, and i’ve had the feeling of more significant progress/impact from biofeedback and neurofeedback as more brief treatment modalities. in talk therapy, i specifically ask for somatic-focused therapy because emotion regulation is an area of higher needs for me. it’s helpful t

i just started with a new therapist & told them right off the bat that “talk therapy” does not work for me. like i know mostly why i do things i do or where it stems from ect but how do i rewire my brain? how do cope? and not just the “5 things you can see”🙄 i picked this therapist specifically beca

same here. my therapist specialises in autistic adults and is an audhder and a queer woman, and these things have really helped me open up with her and trust her. i don’t have to worry about being gaslit about social interactions, or having my gender identity and sexual orientation attacked, or havi

it's good to hear that it helped you. unfortunately, for me, dbt in combination with a bpd misdiagnosis, made me mask more extensively, and i felt gaslit about my experiences as an audhd person. i have been following schema therapy, and that really helps me, especially since it's in a group with oth

i love my therapist and she's done a few different modalities with me from somatic processing to ifs. it's honestly been life changing for me especially with the usual trauma/dissociation most autists grow up with. she also specializes in all these niche areas that are relevant to me, so that helps.
emdr and ifs changed my life. i actually graduated from therapy a couple of years ago. weekly 90 minute sessions for about a year. i can still call if i need to, but i haven’t needed to.

i really like ifs (integrated family systems). it has a lot of structure. while you do still talk about feelings, i have found that i am often talking about them as if they are their own people which makes it feel more tangible and manageable. if you have ever seen the movie inside out, it’s kind of

my dentist is super careful and gentle while opening my mouth and stuff, she also avoids getting the light on my eyes as much as possible. she being a woman helps me be more comfortable, as i don't feel comfortable around men.
always look up recommendations for gentle densits/hygienists. i will quit a bad one and go to another if they hurt me. i like the dentist, it's relaxing.

it really depends on what kind of dentist you have. i have an incredibly nice dentist that i got recommended to by friends. they always talk me through the procedure, which brings me a lot less anxiety and i'm allowed to bring earplugs as well for example. i'd really recommend getting some! also bri

i have the dentist in an hour. get them to explain everything and narrate what they're up to. do close your eyes and bring a fidget. remember that dentists don't like hurting you, it makes them sad and really they are trying very hard to make your life better not worse.

i have a great dentist who explains every step what's she's going to do, what it sounds like and how it's going to feel, and it's great. i close my eyes against the bright light and bring a small fidget toy to distract myself.

100% agree - i swerved it for decades until it got too late - in the end was nowhere near as bad as expected as i told my dentist the reason i hadn’t been was fear, and he couldn’t have been more considerate.

you could ask them to explain every step. i have a great dentist who does this, she walks me through the procedure before starting and checks in with me every so often. i also bring an engraved rock with the rune for courage and recite the respective rune poem over and over again (in my head) to dis
gods i love the x-ray bib, only good thing about going to the dentist

i verbally state what’s important for any practitioner to know before an appointment starts because it’s been my experience that no one actually reviews forms. the forms are to protect them legally. i make sure they are aware of what the big things are (any diagnoses or health stuff i want them to k

aww i'm sorry to hear about your teeth, but congratulations on making and going to the appointment yourself. that's awesome! my fiance just had an appointment he needs 13 fillings. it's going to cost him 5000 over 3 months. i haven't been in 3-4 years, i'm too scared and poor. also my dentist doesn'

the unfortunate thing is that the term was coined because people were already using neurodiversity to just mean autism and adhd, and the person who coined it hoped to encourage its use as a more inclusive term that could encompass any mental difference. it was never meant to be something with a spec

they’re not the most common, dyslexia and dyspraxia are. i have autism and adhd, so there’s nothing that i identify with that is “left out of the neurodivergent conversation”, but those with ocd, tourettes, epilepsy, bpd, bipolar, did, etc. are left out the majority of the time

anxiety disorders absolutely fall under the umbrella of neurodivergence, because they stray from what society deems neurologically typical. autism and adhd are only the very tip of the expansive neurodivergent iceberg (anxiety, depression, ocd, bipolar, tourettes, dyslexia, brain trauma, ptsd, etc.)

actually the most common is dyslexia (10% of the population). i can only guess but my sense from the post is that neurodivergence covers a very wise range of very different neurotypes, and communities can get a bit gate keepy about people who aren't autistic/adhd

and to add to this discussion point. many neurodivergent people have multiple points of cross over into other nd conditions or are a combination for 2-3. an example is many people are auadhd (autistic and adhd) and some people like my own sibling. has autism, some turrets like behaviours, some dysle

it's only harmful if nts weaponized it which can be any word like neuroatypical, neurospicy, or neuroabled. neurotypical-led disability organizations are always quick to steal our self-coined terms and rebrand them as marketing buzzwords that skew the meaning, that's why we're seeing an influx of th

i think you're partly misreading, and partly arguing for a not helpful construction of neurodivergence. towards the misreading part: not all neurodivergence is autism. autism is one of many neurodivergences. people frequently, to the point of problematically, use neurotypical people don't research a

yes, neurodivergent means more than adhd or autism, but i actually don't mind people having these associations... like it's nice to be able to say i'm neurodivergent and not needing to disclose your specific diagnosis... like i fear sometimes telling strangers, that i have schizophrenia (in remissio

it's not about the term itself, but how many people only use it to mention only two disorders included in it when there's dyslexia, tourettes, tbi, learning disabilities, sensory processing disorders, etc. the concept of being neurodivergent and not being autistic or adhd doesn't compute to these so

the worst thing is that they use it that way in academia and the health care and social system. at least here in finland. there's this social councelling service which is catered with neuropsychiatric struggles in mind. you can get in if you have diagnosed adhd or asd. same in school (lower and high

there's no treatment in the sense of a cure, but just like there's no treatment for having no legs, things like ergotherapy can still radically change your life. and masking as a skill is absolutely amazing. it's a tool for being efficient in an alien world. masking as an obligation or a replacement

i’m 51 am undoubtedly neurodivergent but don’t plan to seek a formal diagnosis. the more i learn about how my brain functions differently than nt brains, the more i have “aha” moments about things in my past. learning about masking has been really helpful. i’m awkward and easily overwhelmed - and fr

relatable. i think of masking like dissociation. it has it's uses, you just don't want to get stuck in it. psychology, brain chemistry, and societal patterns are all extremely interesting for me, though i'm not formally educated in them. i still think that information is extremely helpful even thoug
i feel about masking the same way i feel about smoking. i won't judge you, it's your life. but don't pressure others to do it and don't pretend it's healthy.

for me, masking is going into every situation like “how do i play this?”. i always consider where i am, who i’m with, only following their lead as far as how much to share, whether or not to swear, what topics are ok to bring up. it’s like working a corporate job day-out/ day-in. i fit in perfectly

masking, for me, is exerting complete control over everything my body does and says. it’s exhausting. an example of the constant checklist my brain is doing whilst having a conversation -is my facial expression appropriate, is my body language mirroring the person i’m talking to? oh, i feel my smile

i've read your previous comments so i'll take those into consideration here. personally, masking is very tiring to me and it makes me miserable. since starting to mask less, i have noted an uptake in productivity and a more positive self-image which in turn helps me be more motivated. ergo, for me u

does unmasking therapy exist? it's easy to tell someone they should try therapy, but unmasking therapy doesn't seem to exist. i need someone that knows all about unmasking and knows exactly how to help me break free from my mask. i need them to work through the reasons why i mask, and be the first p

how do you know the difference between masking and just basic manners? i have so much anxiety around going to work because of the thought of putting on this fake persona to chat to colleagues etc.i’m starting to wonder if the reason i’m 27 and my counsellors have never got the trigger right for my a

haven’t been here long but haven’t run into that yet. i’m learning how to take my mask off so i know which parts i want to keep and where i want to wear them. even nt folk’s camouflage, it’s just part of engagement with society. there are just a lot more negative aspects of masking for nd folks beca

how many of you all were hypersensitive to noises as a kid then had to go to abusive pseudoscience audio therapy? i remember having to cover my ears over mundane noises like vacuums and such. it seemed so loud especially the higher frequencies. my parents took me to a pseudoscience audio therapy whe

i've heard exposure therapy works for phobias, but not for sensory overload. like some others already pointed out, many nts assume our dislike of certain sounds is fear based, they don't realize the noises are actually hurting us. brain scans have shown that when an autistic person is exposed to the

questions like these are something i still struggle with in relation to dealing with my burnou, i think because i have so thoroughly internalized an nt observer gaze, in my effort to figure out and emulate how i'm supposed to be in the world, that i discount my experience of exhaustion and reduced a

exposure therapy is not good for autistic people. exposure therapy is used mainly for phobias, anxiety disorders, ocd, and ptsd. since autism is not an anxiety disorder and our sensory sensitivities are not caused by anxiety, necessarily, they can not really be helped with exposure therapy. sensory

exposure therapy can work for fear but not pain. touching a hot stove over and over does not make the hot stove less painful and does traumatize the person forced to harm themselves over and over again...

it might never reach the level where you will feel comfortable eating the fruit. but if even seeing it is causing you distress exposure therapy sounds great to help with it. and definitely worth at least discussing it with your therapist. right now you are avoiding the issue, so you are unconsciousl

it is supposed to provide some level of desensitization. it's a bit of a crapshoot, i was told and there haven't been quality large scale studies on whether true desensitization can happen through a regimen like that. there really isn't anything that reliably makes someone significantly less autisti
no, exposure therapy doesn't work for autistic people. we aren't 'irrationally' anxious and therefore we can't increase our tolerance to anxiety-provoking situations.

exposure therapy for autistics? hi guys, i’m a 16 year old autistic female, currently informally diagnosed by my therapist although i will pursue a formal diagnosis eventually. i have an intense phobia of a certain fruit, it’s actually bad enough that i really would prefer to not type the name of th
exposure therapy is for phobias and ptsd. it doesn't work for autism x.x

i didn't think you thought it wasn't real, just poonting out that this diagnosis is thrown on people who don't actually have it due to medical misogyny. i think many social factors play into professionals writing people off with bpd especially if the patient is a woman or afab. any doctor who writes
i wonder if the rampant misdiagnosis of bpd for autistic women by full fledged doctors harms the bpd community :/

i felt the above description could fit me. but bpd, discussed in therapy too never fit. i have a few theories on why bpd is such a popular misdiagnosis. adult diagnosis for autism is tricky however the reputation of the difficulty in affecting change bpd people have may be connected to autistic trai

it actually sounds like bpd to me. i've tried to maintain an open mind, but because of personal experience with people who have borderline personality disorder, i've been resistant to the idea that a lot of autistic women are misdiagnosed. posts like that help me to see where clinicians get it wrong
yes i've heard bpd is a common misdiagnosis in autistic women. sadly that happens to so many!

i’m still 100% convinced that bpd is just modern day “hysteria” they used to diagnose women with decades ago. also convinced a very large number of women who receive that diagnosis are simply just autistic

i was (mis)diagnosed with bpd when i was 20, then adhd and autism at 31. i honestly think bpd is just a bunch of nd symptoms they didn't realise were part of neurodivergence. why do so many women get diagnosed with bpd in their early 20s and almost no men? i think it's because our nd symptoms are di

i wonder what is controversial about it? 🤔 it seems like a pretty great resource. where do you post it thst it gets down voted? i think some people are really really invested in the stigma of bpd, i can understand to some degree if said person was abused by a bpd parent or partner or something, but

i do need to clarify, i don't think that bpd doesn't exist and that people with it definitely fit this category. rather it is a common misdiagnosis. editing to add: i am very biased when it comes to the harm of misdiagnosis. i was misdiagnosed as bipolar and my life was basically ruined by 12 years

i think borderline personality disorder is still a valid diagnosis, it's just thrown around too easily by therapists who want to use it as an explanation for why they aren't able to figure out their patient. i have had 2 people with bpd in my life and.... how to even begin to describe it... those di

yeah my sense is, if he's your husband and you've been on this diagnostic journey for a while, he should know how you've felt about it going in. he should've immediately responded with validation of your lifelong struggle or at the very least asked you how you felt about the diagnosis. his joke resp

it could have been a joke that just didn't land. my wife and i have these all the time, and both suspect we're on the spectrum but have never taken the time to figure out the process of getting a diagnosis. if either of us had said this upon receiving the same news, the other would have laughed thei

yeah my husband and i do not have the kind of relationship where we tease each other (and i hate being teased and always have and he knows it) and i would have been hurt by a comment like that. when i got my diagnosis he basically asked how i feel, told me he’s here to support me, and told me i’m th
two problems: - he immediately made you new diagnosis about him - he sees your new diagnosis as a negative thing (that’s the only way the joke makes sense, i think)

well i'd be pissed if my husband made a joke when i'm first telling him about a diagnosis of any kind. it's not the time to make that kind of joke, it's something very serious. and it's a pretty bad joke. plain rude for me.

it sounds like he missed the point, and made a joke out of his discomfort. how much nicer would it have been if he understood what this diagnosis meant, and said something to show his solidarity? his response revealed a lack of education, comfort, and understanding. he should take this as a chance t

i don't know...this diagnosis was brand new, so he hasn't had the time to ask or assess how she feels about it before knowing it was okay to joke about it that way. when it comes to other people's experiences, i feel it's a pretty base level of decency and respect to let them take the lead on what t

i cringed immediately. has he considered that he's the joke? if i told my most recent ex i had been diagnosed he would either say yes of course or see, your hard work paid off and you got your diagnosis. i'm proud of you, depending on his social battery that day. lol.

whether it was a joke or not, let’s not think about that for a minute. why is that the first thing he says? it’s just a weird thing to say in general about anyone telling you about their diagnosis. it may be a red flag if you feel like things aren’t well in the relationship already, but if everythin

i like this comment. your take and your advice as well as validating her feelings as well as his. his joke was “wrong place wrong time” imho. but in a lighter setting i feel it wouldn’t be too inappropriate. but if it still hurt her feelings regardless, his correct response should just be “im sorry.
this does. not seem like an adhd thing. i'm going to say he's bad at sex. and also kind of an asshole? you deserve better.
being uninterested in pleasing your partner has nothing to do with adhd and i have no idea why you think that it would be, to be honest.

this has nothing to do with adhd or neurodivergent partners. in fact, it’s a bit insulting to even think there’s a connection. many neurodivergent people are actually into kink or are hyper sexual. this has more to do with the fact, you married someone you weren’t compatible with sexually. you can’t

i am neurodivergent (adhd) and i actually hyperfocus on my partners' responses and enjoyment. i get pleasure from giving them pleasure, and i'm good at it. i have had plenty of neurotypical lovers who were selfish and didn't want to learn how to please me, did not care enough to remember how i like

people with adhd are motivated by what they're interested in. things they're not interested in are work and often not things they want to do (i speak from experience, audhd here). with that being said, if he sees having sex with you as work or a chore, it's pretty obvious he doesn't want to do it. s

just curious; what do you get out of the relationship? there must be something other than attraction, desire, and sex that is keeping you with your husband. he's given you a way to have those things in your life, but you continue to seek them from him, even though he's made it clear that he's not in

neurodiverse male with adhd and autism here. your partner is being selfish. sex should be a pleasant experience for both of you, as you undoubtedly know. he can't just ignore your needs because his needs are easier to satisfy. impatience may be the key problem here.
that’s just ridiculous. my partner has mega-adhd and still remembers to check for consent every time, and even figured out on his own how helpful foreplay can be.

adhd or just bad at sex? my husband and i feel incompatible sexually. we have been married 7 years and i always thought the sex would get better, but it hasn’t. i am neurotypical and my husband has adhd. we have been in sex therapy 2 years and it feels to have gone no where.

it's not the adhd. sex with my husband is amazing. he's attentive and pays attention to my body language, he listens to me no matter how deep in the moment we are, and he genuinely wants me to get off every time we have sex. he's the best lover i've ever had, and i think the only person with adhd i'

i did ketamine treatment for a couple months in 2021. i found it extremely helpful and i can still feel the positive effects a year and a half later. i feel like it helped me parce out which parts of me were autism and which parts were responses to trauma, and helped me accept the parts of my autism

i will say that it is a very vulnerable state, while you're getting the infusion, so feel free to be as assertive and cautious as you need to be before deciding for sure that it's what you want to do. for me, i take a sweater, a blanket, a stuffed animal (this one for me is imperative, i have a much

ketamine treatment hello everyone! i'm just curious if any of you have done ketamine treatments (for whatever mental health reason) and if so, how did it go? i have heard lots of first hand accounts of nt people doing ketamine treatment and i'm just curious if it's going to be different for a person

curious if anyone has tried ketamine for autistic burnout? ​ i ask because i've done several ketamine treatment sessions over the past 24 months. i was seeking ketamine treatment because i thought i had treatment resistant depression. but after doing extensive research i'm now convinced that i have

ketamine treatments are done in a doctors office with either nasal spray or an iv and given very little amounts. i don’t plan on taking drugs to get high. i plan on taking medication to be able to function.

hello! my friend has been doing ketamine treatments for a while now and i've been his babysitter. and while he is not technically autistic, he does have more autistic-like traits than most nt people-- namely, high sensitivity to audio and visual stimulation and an acute need for social decompression

ketamine treatment for autism? do they administer strong doses? i never heard of that. i've done ketamine recreationally. it's disassociative so it makes sense that it could help people who are feeling overstimulated
i’ve never heard of that. what exactly does “ketamine treatment” mean?

could you ellaborate on what is an autistic burnout? i think im suffering from it. like, i've not worked for two years. relationships just kill me right now.. i fantazise about a comet wiping out our planet to relax. im just so tired, and it seems related to reading/being read by people. what gets m

what every autistic person going through burnout needs to hear! i recently quit going to therapy after about 6 years because it was absolutely useless and making me feel worse. then i started going to an autistic life coach and already i am feeling like this is helping me more than all of those year
autistic burnout resources does anyone know good resources on autistic burnout, written by autistic people? i'd like to have some to share with nts.

i am currently stuck in autistic burnout for a year. i feel like no one really knows what to do with me and they treat me as if i have a work-related burn out and they don't realise that not only does it affect my work but my whole life. so yes this sounds like a dream for me!

your theory is absolutely plausible. i may have indeed burnt out at the same exact time of my diagnosis. but i do not think this is the case since i talked to all 3 of my gp, phychiatrist and phsychologist about autistic burnout and they all said i dont seem to be in it.

does anyone else fantasise about a retreat for autistic burnout? i’m utterly burnt out. the combination of a high support needs teen, a boss who lacks empathy, a partner who lives an hour away (whom i love dearly) who is a full time carer for his 87 year old mother and the effects of menopause have

i'm generally at a low level of burnout, sometimes higher, but i work very hard to make sure i don't get to full burnout level because i'm worried about this exact scenario. i need to be independent, and while i'm not at risk of losing my employment necessarily, the short-term disability pay is less

i’m only new to finding out i’m autistic (awaiting formal diagnosis but self-determined) and i spent years doing essentially self inflicted ‘exposure therapy’ because i believed i had to to not be lazy or to be valuable. now i’m experiencing the worst autistic burnout of my life. i will have to get
i've had burnout since i started working decades ago and i swear i process things slower now.

some of it is age. over the decades, especially with the rise of social media, on demand everything, my ability to focus and retain information has just disappeared. each burnout just added to the disconnect.

this is precisely what burnout is, and it can definitely have long lasting effect. i’ve been having burnout effects for the better part of 15 years now…and one of the “victims” is my ability to write poetry. i haven’t been able to write like i used to in over a decade. the want is there. the skill i

tl;dr: i don't think healing from burnout is like healing from a broken leg. you don't take it easy for a while, and then go back to your old life. it's finding a new balance that's better for you and actually sustainable, so you don't end in burnout again. i used to have nearly limitless energy to

idk if it's age or what, but each time i've tried to really push for that pure 100% effort it's been sustained for shorter and shorter times. first time i did it i lasted about a year (college). second time lasted about a semester (grad school). at that point i burned out so hard i felt the effects
in my experience, yes. every burnout seems to leave scarring that never fully heals.

yeah i’m still recovering from my last burnout that happened about a year ago. my worst one. when i was sent on immediate sick leave i could no longer read a simple sentence in an email. since then i’ve done some great progress in my recovery but i absolutely don’t feel i’m at the same capacity as b

this makes a lot of sense. i was thinking about this today. like it's not a failure of coping skills, sometimes some abilities just disappear like speaking much, and it's not stubbornness or the silent treatment either. therapy can't bring back neurons that have been blocked by something like days o
this was a fantastic read and felt very nice to be affirmed. do you have other resources on avoiding burnout (preferrable that aren't youtube, i would rather eat a lightbulb.)

there’s nothing wrong with humming is there? if he’s loud but that’s his stim, you either have the option of stopping these things or letting them be. it’s not hurting anyone, and if he’s forced to stop that he’ll probably start acting out in frustration. a lot of aba is about controlling and mouldi

humming is 100% a healthy and harmless stim. i don’t think there’s any reason to teach your son to suppress it. suppressive a harmless stim can cause more harm than good. i would speak to her or even find another therapist who isn’t aba.

i second that! especially as an adult who is still stimming vocally. not because i never got taught how not to, but because sometimes i absolutely have to to deal with a situation at all. there is no good kind of aba from all that i have heard and witnessed, they will always try to make him supress

you should be worried because that is gonna cause harm like you said this is the tricky part of aba when they try an take away positive stimming the humming isn't hurting your kiddo or anyone else they should be allowed to stim like that an be themselves

aba often just teaches us to mask our autism and being forced to mask led me to depression, panic attacks, meltdowns, and self harm as a teen, and eventual burnout as an adult. any child who is happy or concentrating on something or scared and trying to calm themselves...any kid in any of those situ

figure out why he wants to hum and help him with that. maybe you could even help him learn quieter stims. it’s likely the noise or bright lights. aba is only helping him learn that the way he regulates himself is bad.

there's a middle ground ya know. if your child weren't autistic, but was bothering others although being their true selves, what would you do? have you considered shh you're getting a little loud please, and treating them like a regular human? also be advised the humming may be because of the increa

others have said a lot about aba that i agree with so i won’t say more on that. if your son hums loudly in costco then there are alot of sensory triggers there that he needs to stim so loudly. he may be trying to drown out a particular sound with his hums. i would first avoid taking him to costco if

so first, i really would be worried about aba overall but everyone has voiced their opinion well enough on that already. second, i'd actually recommend that you try to make your kid understand that humming in some public places can be disruptive to people. rather than shaming their for the behavior

yeah this is the shitty part of aba humming is harmless, but they don't see it that way. they see any stim as bad and try to stop it. that's not benefitting the child that's benefitting people who don't like being reminded that autistic people exists. it's not making him happy.

this was us, we never did food therapy and he actually did start trying a few things when he was almost 6. yes, much of it is carb and sugar based but at least there is variety. we went from 5 foods to about 20!

yes. we do feeding therapy at our aba center. it is slow going and our daughter is still picky but it has expanded her pallet. she will eat two non-hidden veggies now! yes. we did feeding therapy for a year and it helped tremendously.
